title: Html injection mycrypto.com
content:
Hello. I remembered that a couple of months ago I found an HTML injection vulnerability on myetherwallet.com, I sent it, but my message was ignored. Since you have the same interface, I decided to check this vulnerability on your site and it was reproduced. The vulnerability works both on www.mycrypto.com and on mycrypto.com. Html injection is in a pop-up message  
You are successfully connected
URL: https://www.mycrypto.com/?txHash=qwqwq%3C%20SRC=%22jav ascript: alert (0); "& gt; qwqw # check- tx-status
Network: ETH provided by mycryptoapi.com Unfortunately, you have filtering there, I could not execute js and could hardly display a picture with href on the page. ## PoC https://mycrypto.com/?txHash=qwqwq%3C%20SRC=%22jav ascript:alert(0);"> qwqw#check-tx-status PoC video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JmP9AU8sX5k . ##Impact Since your site and myetherwallet are often subjected to phishing attacks, this vulnerability is dangerous. You can put in the href url of the phishing site, then you can steal the private key of the victim. Perhaps you can upload js to the site, but I could not do it. Impact Since your site and myetherwallet are often subjected to phishing attacks, this vulnerability is dangerous. You can put in the href url of the phishing site, then you can steal the private key of the victim. Perhaps you can upload js to the site, but I could not do it.
steps: Navigate to the URL: https://mycrypto.com/?txHash=qwqwq%3C%20SRC=%22jav ascript:alert(0);"> qwqw#check-tx-status
Observe the HTML injection in the pop-up message where the injected content (image with href) is displayed
vuln_description: The vulnerability is an HTML injection in a pop-up message on mycrypto.com, which allows an attacker to inject arbitrary HTML content, including links and images. While JavaScript execution is filtered, the injection could potentially be used for phishing attacks by embedding malicious links.
reason: The attack is straightforward, involving only the injection of HTML content into a URL parameter. It does not require complex interactions between components or manipulation of application states. The vulnerability is a basic HTML injection, which is a common and well-known issue.

authnz_metadata.reason: The vulnerability involves HTML injection through URL parameters, which is a client-side issue and does not directly relate to authentication or authorization bypasses that the described methodology focuses on. The methodology is designed to detect issues where user sessions or resource IDs are improperly validated in server-side requests, not client-side rendering vulnerabilities.
